title: Just Give Them the Screens (for Now)
description: Apps and shows that won’t make you cringe.
content: “We’re in the midst of something that no one alive has really experienced before,” Dr. Sean O’Leary, M.D., an executive member of the American Academy of Pediatrics’ Committee on Infectious Diseases, told me earlier this week. There’s no handbook for parenting during a pandemic, and we’re all doing our best to adapt to our new circumstances: Our kids may be out of school for weeks, travel is not happening for the foreseeable future and our most intimate interactions will change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: ‘Star Trek: Picard’ Season 1, Episode 8 Recap: That Escalated Quickly
description: The central mystery is further unraveled by the La Sirena crew. But are they moving quickly enough?
content: Man, “Star Trek: Picard” is dark. That is the thought that kept running through my head during this week’s episode. There have been other dark moments throughout the series — but this is the episode when the darkness really stood out. From the start of the episode — when several Romulans stand in a circle, go insane and commit suicide — to Admiral Clancy’s randomly telling Picard to shut up with an unnecessary expletive, I kept thinking that this is a grim world Picard inhabits — and a much different one than the franchise creator, Gene Roddenberry, had in mind decades ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Bortz
title: Curbing Hidden Wedding Costs
description: Don’t let surprise wedding expenses put a dent in your wedding budget. Here are a few hidden fees and miscellaneous items that you can prepare for in advance.
content: Creating and sticking to a budget can be a challenge for couples planning a wedding. The national average cost currently stands at $33,931, according to wedding website the Knot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Snow
title: Riding the Rails With the Man in Seat 61
description: For train travelers, Mark Smith’s website is the go-to source for timetables, maps and booking details in more than 100 countries.
content: Train travel is going through a bit of a renaissance as people reconsider the carbon emissions squashed seating and increasing fees of flying. The man with a front-row seat to the rail resurgence is Mark Smith, the founder of the train travel website The Man in Seat 61. His site has timetables, maps, reviews, booking details and everything else needed to plan train (and even some ferry) trips in more than 100 countries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Acrostic
description: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon, we should all travel by horse.
content: ACROSTIC — Today’s passage is from an essay called “Driving as Metaphor” by Rachel Cusk, a prolific writer of fiction, memoir and commentary. It concerns a primal trait in all of us whereby we often consider the situation we’re in to be especially dire, compared to others, even when we switch positions in the struggle of life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael McDowell
title: She Wanted to Revive a Park. First She Had to Take On the Rats.
description: One woman’s mission to breathe new life into a small slice of Manhattan.
content: Aleya Lehmann watched Verdi Square decay over 16 years of walks down Broadway, from her home on 93rd Street to the Lincoln Center Cinema at 68th Street, a favorite place for a movie and  a box of Cookie Dough Bites.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Special Episode: A Bit of Relief
description: Three Times journalists share what they’re turning to right now for comfort.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: N.B.A. Stars and Owners Say They’ll Cover Workers’ Lost Wages
description: With the season suspended for at least 30 days because of the coronavirus, lower-paid workers at the league’s arenas are getting help from their famous colleagues.
content: Some of the N.B.A.’s biggest stars — including Zion Williamson and Giannis Antetokounmpo — and several team owners said they would help cover the lost income of everyday arena employees while the league goes dark for at least 30 days because of the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Coronavirus Racism Infected My High School
description: A Chinese-American teenager on what she and her friends are encountering during the outbreak.
content: A Chinese-American teenager on what she and her friends are encountering during the outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Trump Tests Negative; Long Waits at U.S. Airports for Inbound Passengers
description: Spain and France have announced countrywide restrictions, and the White House physician says President Trump’s test came back negative.
content: [This briefing has ended. Read the latest updates on the coronavirus epidemic here.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Throw Out the Debate Playbook: Biden and Sanders to Clash Amid Crisis
description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Bernie Sanders will be auditioning for the presidency, trying to convey leadership, against the backdrop of an unfolding national emergency.
content: For the first time in the long Democratic primary campaign, Senator Bernie Sanders of Vermont and former Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. will meet in a one-on-one debate, facing off Sunday night as Mr. Sanders fights for the future of his candidacy against a rival who has taken a commanding position in the race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt
title: Lawmakers Delay Promotion of Officer Involved in Deadly Niger Ambush
description: Col. Bradley D. Moses is the only officer in his unit involved in the 2017 attack to escape some form of punishment.
content: WASHINGTON — The Senate Armed Services Committee has temporarily blocked the promotion of one of the top Special Forces officers involved in the fatal Oct. 4, 2017, ambush in Niger, American officials said Friday. The attack resulted in four American deaths and exposed the U.S. military’s shortcomings in western Africa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Dionne Searcey
title: Trump Supporters Know Where to Turn in a Crisis: To Him
description: They’re confident, for perhaps the first time in his presidency, that the experts on call aren’t out to sabotage the president.
content: In the small town of Jonesborough, Tenn., nestled in the Appalachian Mountains, the Parent Teacher Association group text chat normally lights up with news of school dances and car-pooling schedules. Its main focus now is a global pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Guyana Leader Set to Take New Term After a Vote Denounced as Flawed
description: Electoral officials appear ready to give its president, David E. Granger, another term and control over the country’s new oil riches. Observers cry foul.
content: Guyana’s electoral authorities set the stage for the re-election of the country’s president late Friday, when they declared the country’s ruling party the winner of the capital region, in a widely denounced process that threatens to isolate the small South American nation and new oil producer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Canadian and Italian Hostages Are Freed in Mali After 15 Months
description: Edith Blais and Luca Tacchetto went missing in December 2018, in an area known to be an Islamic State stronghold.
content: A Canadian woman and an Italian man who were abducted 15 months ago in Burkina Faso have been released in the neighboring country of Mali, a United Nations official confirmed Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch
title: Does Coronavirus Mean the End of Sports as We Know Them?
description: Sports were supposed to calm us, distract us. Will the hiatus lead to a reboot, a cleanse?
content: The last game in my town was a girls’ junior-varsity lacrosse game on Thursday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Robert Gebeloff, Steve Eder and Ben Protess
title: These Judges Are Shifting the Appeals Courts to the Right
description: Five takeaways from an examination by The New York Times reveal how President Trump has reshaped the federal judiciary.
content: President Trump made overhauling the federal judiciary one of his top priorities, moving with particular speed to infuse the highly influential appeals courts with reliably conservative judges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rebecca R. Ruiz, Robert Gebeloff, Steve Eder and Ben Protess
title: A Conservative Agenda Unleashed on the Federal Courts
description: President Trump’s imprint on the nation’s appeals courts has been swift and historic. He has named judges with records on a range of issues important to Republicans — and to his re-election.
content: As a Republican candidate for the Texas Supreme Court, Don R. Willett flaunted his uncompromising conservatism, boasting of endorsements from groups with “pro-life, pro-faith, pro-family” credentials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sydney Ember
title: Bernie Sanders, Stand-Up Comic
description: He’s been on the road in 2020 with a serious message about inequality in this country. That doesn’t mean he hasn’t found time to make fun of his age.
content: The question was about age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave and Adam Dean
title: He Took a Bullet to Save His Son in Christchurch. Can They Ever Heal?
description: The attack that claimed 51 lives at two mosques in New Zealand made Zulfirman Syah a hero and a victim. Over the year that followed, he and his family were left to navigate the blind turns of trauma.
content: CHRISTCHURCH, New Zealand — He often sees his 3-year-old son thrashing at the world, screaming “I want to go home” and covering his eyes to avoid glimpsing anyone resembling the Muslim men who were shot beside him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Boris Johnson Pressed to Move Brexit Deadline Amid Coronavirus Threat
description: The schedule for Britain to negotiate its new relationship with the E.U. was already tight. With face-to-face talks on hold, it may be impossible. But Brexiters are already crying foul.
content: LONDON — As leaders on both sides of the English Channel batten down the hatches for the coronavirus, Prime Minister Boris Johnson of Britain is coming under rising pressure to ask the European Union for an extension in its negotiations to reach a trade agreement — in effect, putting off the next stage of Brexit until the virus exits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier
title: Spain Imposes Nationwide Lockdown to Fight Coronavirus
description: A day after an emergency was declared, government officials put in place sweeping restrictions on the public. Stay inside, residents were told.
content: MADRID — Faced with a sharp rise in coronavirus cases, Spain on Saturday became the second country in Europe to impose sweeping restrictions on the public, telling everyone to stay indoors, with limited exceptions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Klinenberg
title: We Need Social Solidarity, Not Just Social Distancing
description: To combat the coronavirus, Americans need to do more than secure their own safety.
content: Social distancing — canceling large gatherings, closing schools and offices, quarantining individuals and even sequestering entire cities or neighborhoods — seems to be the best way to slow the spread of the coronavirus. But it’s a crude and costly public health strategy. Shuttering shared spaces and institutions means families lose child care, wages and social support. What’s more, it’s insufficient to protect the older, sick, homeless and isolated people who are most vulnerable to the virus. They need extra care and attention to survive, not society’s back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Daves, Maura Dwyer and Annie Thoms
title: We Are New York Teachers. Close the Schools.
description: Hand washing can’t prevent our thousands of students, faculty and staff at Stuyvesant High from getting infected and infecting loved ones.
content: We are writing this on behalf of 64 teachers at New York City’s Stuyvesant High who love their students and love their school. That is why we need the city to close it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: There’s a Giant Hole in Pelosi’s Coronavirus Bill
description: The legislation passed by the House doesn’t actually guarantee paid sick leave to most American workers.
content: House Speaker Nancy Pelosi on Friday night celebrated the coronavirus legislation that passed early Saturday as providing paid sick leave to American workers affected by the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Melvoin
title: Here’s Why We Closed Los Angeles Schools
description: They are a place of refuge for nearly 700,000 students. But they can’t protect them from a pandemic.
content: This week, as a member of the Los Angeles Unified School District Board of Education, I voted to declare a state of emergency. On Friday, we made the difficult decision to shut down schools for nearly 700,000 students across 700 square miles for at least the next two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pamela Druckerman
title: Yes, I’m Turning 50. No, I’m Not Really Ready.
description: Someone does still want to sleep with you, but you don’t get to decide who that is. And other lessons for my next decade.
content: PARIS — I turn 50 today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Serge Schmemann
title: Trump’s Chernobyl
description: Thirty-four years ago in Moscow I watched the government mishandle a disaster. Why does it feel like it was just yesterday?
content: It seems terribly wrong that so fine a spring day should be carrying a deadly danger. The daffodils and cherry blossoms proclaim renewal and hope; the crisp, clear air seems incapable of anything so treacherous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jasmine C. Lee
title: How Every House Member Voted on the Coronavirus Relief Bill
description: The sweeping legislation passed the House, 363-40, and will allow for free testing, paid sick leave, stronger unemployment benefits and food security assistance.
content: The sweeping legislation passed the House, 363-40, and will allow for free testing, paid sick leave, stronger unemployment benefits and food security assistance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vincent M. Mallozzi
title: A Blueberry Pie Told Her All She Needed to Know
description: Sean Corley came into Samantha Schneider’s life the day after her best friend died.
content: The day after Samantha Schneider’s best friend died of complications from breast cancer, Sean Corley came into Ms. Schneider’s life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Local and State Officials Unlock Sweeping Powers to Fight Coronavirus
description: At least 40 states and territories have declared states of emergency in response to the virus, giving them the authority to impose curfews, order traffic off the street and mandate quarantines.
content: It might seem there is no more awesome power available to the government than a national emergency declaration like the one President Trump announced on Friday in response to the rapidly spreading coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Protests, Coronavirus and a Baby on the Way
description: A New York Times journalist reflects on the experience of expecting a child while covering Hong Kong’s recent unrest.
content: Our baby was refusing to leave the womb, and who could blame him? Hong Kong, where his parents lived, was reeling from an epic spell of protests and pestilence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ron Lieber
title: Trump’s Student Loan Interest Waiver Isn’t What You May Think
description: President Trump said he was waiving interest on federally held student loans because of the coronavirus outbreak. But payments won’t change.
content: At the end of a week full of talk about bailouts and stimulus, President Trump said Friday afternoon that he was waiving interest on all student loans held by federal government agencies. Right away, the most obvious question was this: How much would monthly payments fall for the tens of millions of borrowers?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: Apple Closes Most of Its Stores for 2 Weeks
description: The tech giant, which will keep its stores in the China region open, becomes one of the first retailers to shut its doors in an effort to halt the spread of the coronavirus.
content: OAKLAND, Calif. — Apple said it would close most of its retail stores outside mainland China, Hong Kong and Taiwan, becoming one of the first companies to take such a drastic measure to fight the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Maggie Haberman
title: Seeking Advice on the Coronavirus, Jared Kushner Enlists a Doctor in the Family
description: Dr. Kurt Kloss, whose daughter, the model Karlie Kloss, is married to Mr. Kushner’s brother, solicited suggestions from a medical Facebook group.
content: One night this week an urgent appeal went out to a Facebook group of emergency room doctors. “If you were in charge of the Federal response to the Pandemic what would your recommendations be?” asked Dr. Kurt Kloss, a physician based in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

title: People Are Loving This Apple Pie
description: Pork noodle soup, chicken Vesuvio, and more recipes.
content: The week’s most popular dishes include Dorie Greenspan’s recipe for apple pie from Circus bakery in Paris (above); Melissa Clark’s asparagus, goat cheese and tarragon tart; and Alison Roman’s pork noodle soup with ginger and toasted garlic. Find more recipes in the collection below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: At the Library, Last Call for Beauty and Books
description: As the New York Public Library’s magnificent 42nd Street reading room prepared to close temporarily because of the virus, regulars wondered when they would be back.
content: New York has been roiled with closures of cultural institutions this week, since the effort to stop the coronavirus kicked into high gear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Mele
title: Cap and Gone? College Commencements Confront the Coronavirus
description: The University of Michigan canceled its planned ceremony while students at the University of Maine threw an impromptu “Coronamencement.”
content: The University of Michigan on Friday canceled its commencement planned for May over fears of the coronavirus — one of what is likely to be many such college ceremonies to be reconsidered in the face of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
title: Trump Administration Is Relaxing Oversight of Nursing Homes
description: A proposal would loosen federal rules meant to control infections, just as the coronavirus rips through nursing homes.
content: The Trump administration has been working to relax regulations governing America’s nursing homes, including rules meant to curb deadly infections among elderly residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Herb Goldsmith, the Man Behind the Members Only Jacket, Dies at 92
description: An aggressive marketer, he used celebrities to promote his brand. Frank Sinatra, Johnny Carson and two presidents wore his jackets.
content: The men’s clothing entrepreneur Herb Goldsmith had an instinct for capturing the public eye.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas
title: He Has 17,700 Bottles of Hand Sanitizer and Nowhere to Sell Them
description: Amazon cracked down on coronavirus price gouging. Now, while the rest of the world searches, some sellers are holding stockpiles of sanitizer and masks.
content: On March 1, the day after the first coronavirus death in the United States was announced, brothers Matt and Noah Colvin set out in a silver S.U.V. to pick up some hand sanitizer. Driving around Chattanooga, Tenn., they hit a Dollar Tree, then a Walmart, a Staples and a Home Depot. At each store, they cleaned out the shelves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and Katie Rogers
title: On a Saturday Night in Florida, a Presidential Party Became a Coronavirus Hot Zone
description: A weekend getaway at Mar-a-Lago put the president in contact with several people who later tested positive for the virus. The White House physician said the president had tested negative for the virus.
content: WASHINGTON — The lights were low and the disco balls spinning as a cake with a fiery sparkler shooting flames into the air was brought out to a robust rendition of “Happy Birthday,” joined by President Trump. The birthday girl, Kimberly Guilfoyle, the girlfriend of Donald Trump Jr., then pumped her fist in the air and called out, “Four more years!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Chinese Tycoon Who Criticized Xi’s Response to Coronavirus Has Vanished
description: Ren Zhiqiang appears to be the latest government critic silenced by the Communist Party as it cracks down on dissent over the epidemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck and Thomas Kaplan
title: ‘Am I on Camera?’ Joe Biden’s Foray Into Virtual Campaigning
description: Technical glitches disrupted Mr. Biden’s virtual town hall with voters in Illinois on Friday. Bernie Sanders held an online “fireside chat’’ on Saturday. It’s the new paradigm for candidates amid a health crisis.
content: For Joseph R. Biden Jr., campaigning these days means virtual fund-raisers. Shuttered field offices. And rallying support by live stream, a tactic vulnerable to severe technological difficulties, as he discovered on Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Jim Tankersley
title: Here’s What’s in Congress’s Emergency Coronavirus Bill
description: The package includes free coronavirus testing for all, but its two weeks of paid sick don’t apply to many workers. The Senate is expected to take up the measure early next week.
content: WASHINGTON — The House passed an emergency relief package Saturday to address the sweeping effects of the coronavirus and cushion the economic blow to the most vulnerable Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines
title: How the Coronavirus Could Hurt the Accuracy of the 2020 Census
description: Many people were already hard to count or suspicious of participating in the census. The virus will amplify those problems.
content: WASHINGTON — As the first invitations to complete forms for the 2020 census land in mailboxes this week, federal and local leaders are scrambling to counter the coronavirus pandemic that poses a last-minute threat to a decade’s worth of preparation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Internet Providers Won’t Cut Off Users Over Unpaid Bills for 60 Days
description: The pledge some companies took, in the face of the coronavirus pandemic, also calls for them to open public Wi-Fi hot spots and waive late fees, the F.C.C. said.
content: AT&T, Comcast and dozens of other telecommunications firms have committed to not disconnecting service to residential and small business customers who can’t pay their bills because of the coronavirus outbreak, the Federal Communications Commission said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Out With the Rats, In With the Butterflies
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, March 14, 2020.
content: “We were diving into a foot-deep mystery pile of rats.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Sona Patel
title: Schools Close Over Coronavirus Concerns
description: Saturday: California’s largest school districts have shut down, affecting more than 1,000,000 students across the state.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Porter
title: Why America Will Never Get Medicare for All
description: Forget politics or money. Racism explains why the country lacks the safety net its citizens deserve.
content: The weirdest thing about the Democratic primary is how un-American it sounds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Enrich
title: Trump Is Losing Money in the Markets, Too
description: President Trump’s investments in stocks and bonds are holding up no better than the S&P 500.
content: President Trump, the first self-proclaimed billionaire to occupy the White House, has long asserted that he is one of the world’s best businessmen and investors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Hafner
title: How to Protect Older People From the Coronavirus
description: People over 60, and especially over 80, are particularly vulnerable to severe or fatal infection. Here are some steps to reduce their risk.
content: Amid the uncertainty swirling around the coronavirus pandemic stands one incontrovertible fact: The highest rate of fatalities is among older people, particularly those with underlying medical conditions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keeanga-Yamahtta Taylor
title: Why Sanders Isn’t Winning Over Black Voters
description: People with the most to gain from his agenda have also been the most disappointed by politics.
content: The story about Bernie Sanders is that he can’t win black voters. That first emerged when he lost the Democratic presidential nomination in 2016 and was reinforced by Joe Biden’s decisive sweep of Southern primaries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Full Appeals Court to Decide Whether Congress Can Sue Executive Branch
description: The court took up disputes over funding for President Trump’s border wall and a subpoena to Donald F. McGahn II, his former White House counsel.
content: WASHINGTON — The entire federal appeals court in Washington said on Friday that it would take up two cases that raised the question of whether and when Congress may sue to resolve a dispute with the president, setting up a double-barreled test for establishing when the judicial branch can resolve disputes over separation of powers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: March 14, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, March 14, 2020.
content: An article on Thursday about a secret extrajudicial location where the Greek government is detaining migrants referred incompletely to the nationality of Somar al-Hussein. While Mr. al-Hussein is a Syrian Kurd, he is also one of a small minority of Syrian exiles to recently receive a Turkish passport.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: It’s Office-Bound
description: Peter Wentz brings us flowers and a vibrant Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — I trust that everyone is enjoying a little extra puzzle time and staying productive, not getting stir crazy at all. Today we have a Peter Wentz construction, his first for 2020; it comes with 10 debuts and a generous sprinkle of fun clues and misdirects.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winnie Hu
title: A Surge in Biking to Avoid Crowded Trains in N.Y.C.
description: More New Yorkers are turning to cycling to minimize their coronavirus exposure. Citi Bike trips surged to more than half a million this month.
content: Halimah Marcus’s bike had been collecting dust for five years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Did Sexism Doom Elizabeth Warren’s Bid?
description: Readers offer different diagnoses for why Ms. Warren faltered, ranging from misogyny to likability to policies.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: The Milk Situation
description: Americans have been souring on dairy milk for decades. Here’s how farmers are trying to win us back.
content: For two fleeting decades, there was no status symbol more potent than the milk mustache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Michel Roux, 78, Dies; Helped Bring French Cuisine to London
description: He was appalled by English food, particularly peas. With his brother, he established the first British restaurant to win three Michelin stars.
content: Michel Roux, a French-born chef who lifted fine dining in London to a new plane in the late 1960s when, with his older brother, Albert, he opened Le Gavroche, the first British restaurant to earn three Michelin stars, died on Wednesday at his home in Bray-on-Thames. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: For Many Athletes, Coronavirus Means the End of College Careers
description: “It feels like all the hard work — I don’t want to say it’s for nothing, but you want to compete.”
content: LAS VEGAS — As the final seconds wound down, Utah State guard Sam Merrill dribbled the ball back and forth between his legs and rocked closer to the 3-point line until, with a burst, he took a hard dribble followed by a crow hop to his left. He then let fly a 25-foot jumper over the outstretched hand of San Diego State guard K.J. Feagin, who had been hounding Merrill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: An Important Year for Women’s Sports, Paused by Coronavirus
description: Female athletes already fight for money, screen time and other resources. Work stoppages over coronavirus concerns threaten opportunities to move forward.
content: This was set to be a groundbreaking year for women’s sports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Ready, Set … Get Slow!
description: Nancy Stark and Will Nediger swoop in with a merrily muddled Sunday puzzle.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — The part of my brain that usually comes up with witticisms and observations for crossword posts is flashing “otherwise occupied,” so I will contrast the cleverness of today’s Will Nediger and Nancy Stark collaboration by playing it straight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ginia Bellafante
title: The Rich Have a Coronavirus Cure: Escape From New York
description: When fake rumors inspired a run on toilet paper, the 1 percent made a panicked exodus to their second homes.
content: By Thursday afternoon, texts and emails circulating among New York’s professional class warned that perhaps it was time to leave. The city was going into lockdown, or at least that’s what people were saying — probably by Friday morning. No one really knew this but now, you did.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Trump Is Tested for Coronavirus, and Experts Ask: What Took So Long?
description: Federal officials are asking Americans for extraordinary vigilance against a new pathogen. President Trump has taken a different course, worrying scientists.
content: After hosting a gathering with guests later found to be infected with the coronavirus, President Trump refrained from getting tested, let alone from self-quarantine, even as administration officials urged Americans to adopt stern new precautions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Trump Says He Could Demote Fed Chair Powell, Risking More Market Turmoil
description: At a time of grave investor uncertainty over the coronavirus, economists warned that the president could throw fuel on the fire.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Saturday that he had the power to remove or demote Jerome H. Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, renewing a long-running threat against the central bank’s leader at a time when it could further roil volatile markets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter, Raphael Minder and Elian Peltier
title: Shutdowns Spread Across Europe as Spain and France Order Broad Restrictions
description: Other European countries are turning to border closures to try to contain the coronavirus.
content: PARIS — The shutdown of Europe expanded drastically on Saturday, as more countries shuttered businesses, locked up borders and chased people off streets and into their homes in a race to contain the growing threat of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Soccer the Sport Must Stop. Soccer the Business Probably Can’t.
description: The sport’s hand was forced by the mounting number of cases within the game, but the decision to halt matches was slowed by the potential consequences.
content: Enjoying this newsletter every week? Send it to a friend, or six, or 10, and tell them to sign up at nytimes.com/rory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Could the 2020 Election Be Postponed? Only With Great Difficulty. Here’s Why.
description: With Louisiana and Georgia delaying their primary votes, we answer six key questions about holding elections in a crisis. And no, a president cannot cancel an election with executive authority.
content: The coronavirus outbreak is inflicting new disruptions on the 2020 presidential campaign by the day, but few compare to the decisions by Louisiana and Georgia over the past 48 hours to reschedule their upcoming primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iona Hires Rick Pitino as Its New Coach
description: Pitino, a Hall of Famer, had been out of college basketball since 2017, when he was fired from Louisville amid a federal investigation.
content: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. (AP) — The Hall of Fame coach Rick Pitino was named the new leader of the men’s basketball program at Iona College on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Iona Hires Rick Pitino as Its New Coach
description: Pitino, a Hall of Famer, had been out of college basketball since 2017, when he was fired from Louisville amid a federal investigation.
content: NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y. (AP) — The Hall of Fame coach Rick Pitino was named the new leader of the men’s basketball program at Iona College on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: 51 Judges Named by Trump
description: Appointees by the president make up more than a quarter of the appellate bench, populating seats on 11 of the 13 circuits. This was their path to confirmation.
content: The list below is part of a broad examination in The New York Times of President Trump’s transformation of the federal judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexander Burns
title: Could the 2020 Election Be Postponed? Only With Great Difficulty. Here’s Why.
description: With Louisiana and Georgia delaying their primary votes, we answer six key questions about holding elections in a crisis. And no, a president cannot cancel an election with executive authority.
content: The coronavirus outbreak is inflicting new disruptions on the 2020 presidential campaign by the day, but few compare to the decisions by Louisiana and Georgia over the past 48 hours to reschedule their upcoming primary elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Italians Find ‘a Moment of Joy in This Moment of Anxiety’
description: Under lockdown to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, song breaks out from rooftops, balconies and windows.
content: ROME — It started with the national anthem. Then came the piano chords, trumpet blasts, violin serenades and even the clanging of pots and pans — all of it spilling from people’s homes, out of windows and from balconies, and rippling across rooftops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Genesis Breyer P-Orridge, Musician, Artist and Provocateur, Dies at 70
description: Genesis achieved cult notoriety leading the British rock bands Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV, and later pushed the limits of gender in a surgical project to merge identities with her wife.
content: Genesis Breyer P-Orridge, the provocative British musician, writer and visual artist who pushed the limits of gender and the self, often using her own skin as her medium, has dropped her body.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee
title: Saudi Law Granted Women New Freedoms. Their Families Don’t Always Agree.
description: Women in the conservative kingdom are finding they have to negotiate with their relatives newly granted permissions to work, drive and travel.
content: MEDINA, Saudi Arabia — On the question of women working, the law of the land was crystal clear. Raghda and Rafaa Abuazzah’s parents had ruled otherwise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Campbell Robertson
title: ‘We’ve Got a Monster That’s Looming’: West Virginia Is the Last State Without a Coronavirus Case
description: The state has a greater share of adults at risk than any other state in the country, according to a recent study.
content: CHARLES TOWN, W.Va. — There are plenty of reasons West Virginia, as of Saturday afternoon, was the only state in the country with no confirmed cases of the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Man Sentenced to 54 Years for Crash That Killed 3 Girl Scouts and a Mother
description: The authorities said Colten Treu was high on an inhalant when he drove into a troop of Girl Scouts and parents who were cleaning the side of a road in Wisconsin.
content: A Wisconsin man who plowed a pickup truck into a troop of Girl Scouts who were picking up trash on the side of a road, killing three girls and one mother, was sentenced this week to 54 years in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Oung
title: Coronavirus Racism Infected My High School
description: A Chinese-American teenager on what she and her friends are encountering during the outbreak.
content: What happens when stereotypes and fear about Covid-19 arrive before the actual disease does? In the video above, Katherine Oung, a 11th grader in Florida, shows what teenagers like her and her friends face as the coronavirus pandemic brings to the surface the racism underlying her community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: The Christian Response to the Coronavirus: Stay Home
description: When loving your neighbor means keeping your distance.
content: The church, the actual building that houses black bodies and souls, stands at the center of black life and culture. It is a fact hiding in plain sight that one of the first cooperative economic ventures former slaves undertook was the purchase and maintenance of churches. Without the cooperation of the church, many black colleges, universities and political organizations would not exist. To this day, American black Christians attend church at a higher rate than any other ethnic group.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni and Damon Winter
title: She Went Blind. Then She Danced.
description: “We’re alive! As long as we’re alive, we have to keep moving.”
content: There are different responses to unexpected hardship, and when Marion Sheppard began to go blind, she cycled through many of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Fix Those Cracking, Crumbling Plaster Walls
description: There are two kinds of cracks in old lath and plaster walls. Both can be repaired, but one is a much more serious problem.
content: Q: Our Gramercy co-op was built in 1929. The thick plaster walls have so many benefits, but no sooner do we paint a room than new cracks appear. The ceiling plaster is another problem. It wants to come down in big, thick pieces. I asked our super if we could put sheet rock on the ceiling and start fresh, but he said there would be no good way to affix it. What can I do to prevent or repair cracking in the walls? Or can I cover them with wallpaper? And how do I repair the ceiling?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Hobbs & Shaw’ and ‘Funny Women’
description: The “Fast & Furious” spinoff starring Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham airs on HBO, while veteran comedians perform on Showtime.
content: FAST & FURIOUS PRESENTS: HOBBS & SHAW (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. We have come a long way since Vin Diesel and Paul Walker played Californian street racers in 2001’s “The Fast and the Furious.” The franchise has ballooned since then, and its latest offering is this spinoff. In “Hobbs & Shaw,” which takes place between “Fate of the Furious” (2017) and the upcoming “F9,” Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham reprise their roles from earlier “Furious” movies, reluctantly teaming up to keep a genetically enhanced supervillain (Idris Elba) from getting his hands on a deadly virus. Their mission ties in Shaw’s formidable sister (Vanessa Kirby), a rogue MI6 agent, and takes them to Chernobyl and then Samoa. The plot is hardly the point — the main attraction is the scathing banter between the leading men and the over-the-top, gravity-defying stunts. It may not be the strongest film in the saga, but it’s a fun escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens and Maggie Astor
title: Biden Builds a Lead as Sanders Presses On: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: The coronavirus has dominated the news and is wreaking havoc on the political world. Nonetheless, the race for the Democratic nomination continues (with some modifications).
content: We know you probably didn’t come to a politics roundup for more news about the coronavirus. But it has upended the Democratic primary, Washington and politics writ large just as it has upended sports, culture and the rest of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox Business Benches Trish Regan After Outcry Over Coronavirus Comments
description: The host of “Trish Regan Primetime” told viewers this week that concerns about the coronavirus were “yet another attempt to impeach the president.”
content: The Fox Business anchor Trish Regan, whose on-air dismissal of the coronavirus as “another attempt to impeach the president” left her cable network facing a firestorm of criticism this week, has been removed from her prime-time slot for the foreseeable future, the network said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: We Need Real Economic Stimulus
description: The coronavirus is pushing down growth and risking recession.
content: At long last, the president declared a national emergency on Friday that took aim at some of the specific repercussions of the coronavirus pandemic. And Congress is moving forward with its own, smaller package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz and Julia Jacobs
title: Ticketholders Seek Refunds as Coronavirus Prompts Mass Cancellations
description: For many events, it’s not too late to get your money back.
content: With governments and health officials trying to limit the spread of the coronavirus by discouraging or banning large gatherings, the highly contagious virus has had a palpable impact on the plans of would-be vacationers, theatergoers, sports fans and others.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacy Cowley and Anupreeta Das
title: A Bank in Midtown Is Cleaned Out of $100 Bills
description: Large-denomination bills were in such high demand this week that at least one Bank of America branch wasn’t able to satisfy some customers pulling out tens of thousands of dollars at a time.
content: As the stock market was having its worst day in 30 years on Thursday, customers at a Bank of America branch in Midtown Manhattan, the financial heart of New York, were lining up to take cash out of their accounts — sometimes tens of thousands of dollars at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Sokol
title: They Knew Saber-toothed Tigers Were Big. Then They Found This Skull.
description: The find suggests that the prehistoric predators might have been able to feed on even the most giant prey of the Pleistocene era.
content: When the curator mentioned a huge saber-toothed tiger skull stored behind the scenes of the National Museum of Natural History in Montevideo, Uruguay, Aldo Manzuetti had to see for himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Qiu
title: Trump’s False Claims About His Response to the Coronavirus
description: The president inaccurately described travel restrictions he had announced, falsely blamed his predecessor for testing shortages and misstated the role Google was playing in mitigating the outbreak.
content: As he declared a national emergency over the coronavirus outbreak, President Trump attempted to deflect criticisms of his administration’s response to the virus with inaccurate claims. Here’s a fact-check.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: These Lab Animals Will Help Fight Coronavirus
description: Scientists are ramping up the breeding of lab mice as well as the testing of primates and other animals, but it all takes time.
content: Among the many lessons of the coronavirus pandemic is how close humans are to the rest of the animal kingdom. We get diseases from other animals, and then we use more animals to figure out how to stop the diseases. As research ramps up treatments and vaccines, animals are crucial to fighting the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

title: 2 New York State Lawmakers Test Positive for Coronavirus
description: The number of confirmed cases in the state is now 613, including 269 in New York City, officials said.
content: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo announced on Saturday night that two State Assembly members from Brooklyn had tested positive for the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Inside the Most Secret Place at Guantánamo Bay
description: At Camp 7, the military holds prisoners who were previously held and interrogated by the C.I.A. But in recent years, conditions have eased up a bit.
content: This article was produced in partnership with the Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein and Brian M. Rosenthal
title: Coronavirus in N.Y.: Will a Surge in Patients Overwhelm Hospitals?
description: “We are not prepared,” one doctor said. New York City’s hospitals may be moving too slowly as the outbreak spreads, experts say.
content: Two of the biggest hospital systems in the Northeast — New York City’s Health and Hospitals Corporation and NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital — plan to cancel nonemergency surgeries. NYU Langone Medical Center’s Tisch Hospital turned a pediatric emergency room into a respiratory ward for adults. Northwell Health, which has a sprawling network of hospitals, is asking retired nurses to return to work.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sara Aridi
title: What’s on TV Saturday: ‘Hobbs & Shaw’ and ‘Funny Women’
description: The “Fast & Furious” spinoff starring Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham airs on HBO, while veteran comedians perform on Showtime.
content: FAST & FURIOUS PRESENTS: HOBBS & SHAW (2019) 8 p.m. on HBO; stream on HBO platforms. We have come a long way since Vin Diesel and Paul Walker played Californian street racers in 2001’s “The Fast and the Furious.” The franchise has ballooned since then, and its latest offering is this spinoff. In “Hobbs & Shaw,” which takes place between “Fate of the Furious” (2017) and the upcoming “F9,” Dwayne Johnson and Jason Statham reprise their roles from earlier “Furious” movies, reluctantly teaming up to keep a genetically enhanced supervillain (Idris Elba) from getting his hands on a deadly virus. Their mission ties in Shaw’s formidable sister (Vanessa Kirby), a rogue MI6 agent, and takes them to Chernobyl and then Samoa. The plot is hardly the point — the main attraction is the scathing banter between the leading men and the over-the-top, gravity-defying stunts. It may not be the strongest film in the saga, but it’s a fun escape.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: How to Fix Those Cracking, Crumbling Plaster Walls
description: There are two kinds of cracks in old lath and plaster walls. Both can be repaired, but one is a much more serious problem.
content: Q: Our Gramercy co-op was built in 1929. The thick plaster walls have so many benefits, but no sooner do we paint a room than new cracks appear. The ceiling plaster is another problem. It wants to come down in big, thick pieces. I asked our super if we could put sheet rock on the ceiling and start fresh, but he said there would be no good way to affix it. What can I do to prevent or repair cracking in the walls? Or can I cover them with wallpaper? And how do I repair the ceiling?

title: Biden Builds a Lead as Sanders Presses On: This Week in the 2020 Race
description: The coronavirus has dominated the news and is wreaking havoc on the political world. Nonetheless, the race for the Democratic nomination continues (with some modifications).
content: We know you probably didn’t come to a politics roundup for more news about the coronavirus. But it has upended the Democratic primary, Washington and politics writ large just as it has upended sports, culture and the rest of society.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum
title: Fox Business Benches Trish Regan After Outcry Over Coronavirus Comments
description: The host of “Trish Regan Primetime” told viewers this week that concerns about the coronavirus were “yet another attempt to impeach the president.”
content: The Fox Business anchor Trish Regan, whose on-air dismissal of the coronavirus as “another attempt to impeach the president” left her cable network facing a firestorm of criticism this week, has been removed from her prime-time slot for the foreseeable future, the network said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: As China Cracks Down on Coronavirus Coverage, Journalists Fight Back
description: The Communist Party is trying to fill the airwaves with positive stories about its battle against the virus. Chinese reporters, buoyed by widespread calls for free speech, are resisting.
content: When Jacob Wang saw reports circulating online recently suggesting that life was getting better in Wuhan, the center of the coronavirus outbreak, he was irate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: Please, Don’t Go Out to Brunch Today
description: Gathering in groups right now is selfish and puts the lives of others at risk.
content: The coronavirus and the disease it causes, Covid-19, are spreading across the United States faster than we can track or test. This week the confirmed caseload jumped from 309 to at least 2,170 cases in 49 states, as well as the District of Columbia and Puerto Rico. A testing shortage has experts fearing the true number is likely thousands of cases higher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: The Companies Putting Profits Ahead of Public Health
description: As the coronavirus spreads, the public interest requires employers to abandon their longstanding resistance to paid sick leave.
content: Most American restaurants do not offer paid sick leave. Workers who fall sick face a simple choice: Work and get paid or stay home and get stiffed. Not surprisingly, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention reported in 2014 that fully 20 percent of food service workers had come to work at least once in the previous year “while sick with vomiting or diarrhea.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: Plagued by the President
description: Trump washes his hands of responsibility.
content: WASHINGTON — Paging Proust. For me, this is the week when memories rush back from childhood: watching my parents get gussied up for St. Patrick’s Day parades and banquets, green carnations pinned to their lapels; the family’s annual excursion to the Tidal Basin to catch the fleeting pink splendor of the cherry blossoms.
source.name: The New York Times
